newsitem.title: USA: N.J. Salem 2 nuke seen ready to restart next week.
newsitem.headline: N.J. Salem 2 nuke seen ready to restart next week.

text.p: The 1,106 megawatt (MW) unit 2 at the Salem nuclear power plant in southern New Jersey was planned to be ready to restart next week, the operator Public Service Electric & Gas Co (PSE&G) said Monday.
Salem 2's reactor was cooled from "hot standby" to "cold shutdown" mode last week after engineers discovered problems with the unit's spray valves.
"We're finishing repairs by the early part of this week. They'll test again. We should be back to normal operating temperature by next week," a PSE&G spokeswoman said.
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) has withheld restart approval for Salem 2 until it receives word from PSE&G that the unit is in safe condition to startup after the valve repairs.
PSE&G had hoped to restore Salem 2 to service before the end of July.
Salem 2 and adjoining unit 1, with the same generating capacity, have been shut for more than two years due to safety concerns raised by the NRC.
Salem 2 was physically ready to resume operation before the valve problem cropped up.
"We're satisfied that they've met those issues. It's a matter of them fine-tuning," a NRC spokesman said, referring to the valve work underway.
In addition to PSE&G, PECO Energy Co, Atlantic Energy Co and Delmarva Power & Light Co are the other owners of the Salem units.
